prior_works.title: Algorithmic Learning in a Random World
prior_works.authors: Vladimir Vovk, Alex Gammerman, Glenn Shafer
prior_works.role: Foundational framework for conformal prediction and conformity scores
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s core idea—wrapping CATE estimators with a distribution-free predictive interval—directly instantiates the conformal prediction framework introduced by Vovk et al., using conformity scores to obtain marginally valid coverage.

prior_works.title: Distribution-Free Predictive Inference for Regression
prior_works.authors: Jing Lei, Max G'Sell, Alessandro Rinaldo, Ryan Tibshirani, Larry Wasserman
prior_works.role: Split conformal methodology enabling scalable, model-agnostic prediction intervals
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Conformal meta-learners operationalize split conformal prediction on top of CATE meta-learners exactly in the spirit of Lei et al., adopting residual-based conformity scores and sample splitting to guarantee marginal validity.

prior_works.title: Metalearners for Estimating Heterogeneous Treatment Effects Using Machine Learning
prior_works.authors: Sören R. Künzel, Jasjeet S. Sekhon, Peter J. Bickel, Bin Yu
prior_works.role: Introduced S-, T-, and X-learner templates for CATE via nuisance-learning and two-stage regression
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The proposed conformal meta-learners explicitly build on the meta-learner paradigm of Künzel et al., extending these templates from point estimation to predictive intervals for individual treatment effects.

prior_works.title: Quasi-Oracle Estimation of Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
prior_works.role: R-learner: orthogonalized two-stage pseudo-outcome regression for CATE
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s stochastic-ordering validity analysis is developed for two-stage pseudo-outcome regression schemes such as the R-learner, and it verifies conditions under which R-learner-based conformity scores yield valid predictive inference.

prior_works.title: Optimal Doubly Robust Estimation of Heterogeneous Treatment Effects
prior_works.role: DR-learner: doubly robust pseudo-outcome construction for CATE with orthogonalization
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By treating DR-learner pseudo-outcomes as the target of conformal scoring, the paper shows when these scores stochastically dominate oracle ITE scores, thereby delivering marginally valid predictive intervals.

prior_works.title: Double/Debiased Machine Learning for Treatment and Structural Parameters
prior_works.authors: Victor Chernozhukov, Denis Chetverikov, Mert Demirer, Esther Duflo, Christian Hansen, Whitney Newey, James Robins
prior_works.role: Orthogonalization and cross-fitting to stabilize inference with learned nuisance functions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The conformal meta-learner framework leverages DML’s orthogonal scores and cross-fitting ideas to construct pseudo-outcomes whose estimation errors minimally affect conformity scores, supporting the paper’s validity guarantees.

prior_works.title: Targeted Maximum Likelihood Learning
prior_works.authors: Mark J. van der Laan, Daniel Rubin
prior_works.role: Influence-function-based, doubly robust targeted learning underpinning pseudo-outcome construction
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s two-stage pseudo-outcome regression and emphasis on efficient influence–function–based targets trace to TMLE principles, which motivate the doubly robust, orthogonal pseudo-outcomes used for conformal calibration.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s key contribution—conformal meta-learners that provide distribution-free predictive intervals for individual treatment effects—emerges by fusing two mature literatures: conformal prediction and meta-learning for heterogeneous treatment effects. On the conformal side, Vovk–Gammerman–Shafer established the basic conformity-score machinery and marginal coverage guarantees, while Lei et al. provided the split conformal recipe that makes model-agnostic, finite-sample predictive inference practical. On the causal side, meta-learner templates by Künzel et al. (S/T/X-learners) codified how to assemble nuisance models into CATE estimators via two-stage regression. Orthogonalization-centric learners—Nie and Wager’s R-learner and Kennedy’s DR-learner—supplied pseudo-outcomes whose construction attenuates nuisance estimation error, a property formalized by Chernozhukov et al.’s double/debiased machine learning framework through Neyman-orthogonal scores and cross-fitting. TMLE (van der Laan and Rubin) further grounds the use of influence-function-based targets and doubly robust pseudo-outcomes that are amenable to stable second-stage regression. The present paper bridges these streams by applying split conformal prediction to the pseudo-outcomes generated by meta-learners and introducing a stochastic ordering criterion: marginal validity follows when pseudo-outcome conformity scores dominate the unattainable oracle ITE scores. It then verifies this condition for widely used two-stage learners (e.g., R/DR/X), thereby transforming point-estimation meta-learners into conformal meta-learners with rigorous predictive intervals for ITEs.
